This transform takes a complex-valued function of a real variable and transforms it into a function of the complex variable \\( s \\).

If the Laplace transform \\( \\mathcal{L} \\) is applied to \\( z(x) \\) without any additional functional transformation, will the poles of \\( \\mathcal{L}(z)(s) \\) solely depend on the characteristics of \\( u \\) and \\( v \\)?

Any poles in \\( \\mathcal{L}(z)(s) \\) arise due to characteristics inherent in these underlying functions, reflecting their rates of increase or points of discontinuity.
